title: Scotland vs Russia, Rugby World Cup 2019 LIVE: Latest score and updates
text:
Follow the latest updates live from the Rugby World Cup as Scotland look to keep their quarter-final hopes alive against Russia in Pool A.

The Scots continue to try and rebuild their campaign following the opening defeat against Ireland, and after a crushing 34-0 victory over Samoa, Gregor Townsend’s side can close right up onto the tail of the Irish in the battle for the top two spots.

Scotland will be expected to win, but they need to ensure they do a professional job and guarantee the bonus point too, which would give them a chance of beating Japan in Sunday’s Pool A showdown and reaching the last eight. Follow the live updates below.

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

Rugby World Cup latest news Scotland vs Russia kicks off at 8:15am BST

Scotland must win with a bonus point to have realistic hopes of reaching quarter-finals

This could be our final chance to see Russia at a World Cup for a while. The Bears only made this tournament courtesy of a couple of eligibility mishaps from other European nations, and there is a sense that the standard in other parts of Europe, notably Spain, Romania and Germany, may be improving to such an extent that Russia will be left behind. So, perhaps, one too savour. The Russians have had a good tournament, and have on the whole been more competitive than warm-up defeats to Jersey and Connacht suggested. I love this group of Scotland backs. George Horne and Adam Hastings take the reins in the halves, with Hastings very much in the Finn Russell mould with creative attacking play from both hand and foot, and Horne a livewire around the fringes with a superb running game. Pete Horne is a canny footballer at 12, Duncan Taylor solid as anything at 13, but it is out wide where the real excitement comes. Tommy Seymour is back in and in need of a strong performance, and he's joined by an extremely exciting young Edinburgh pair. Darcy Graham showed a little bit of what he can do against Samoa and is dynamite in open space, and Blair Kinghorn is a personal favourite, with a howitzer of a boot and a stride length to cross the Firth of Forth in three elongated bounds. Russia can't afford to kick loosely, and I'm expecting Scotland to score a few tries today. It has been a disappointing tournament for Scotland, with a woefully ineffectual opening game against Ireland and injuries to a number of key contributors. They rather ground out the bonus point win against Samoa, but never truly found their attacking flow. That will be on their to do list today, albeit with a second-choice backline. Talking of which... Super typhoon threatens England and Scotland games after intensifying Team News - Russia Russia are without their two 2019 World Cup point-scorers - Kirill Golosnitskiy is out after colliding with the post padding in their defeat to Ireland, while fly-half Yury Kushnarev is dropped to the bench. Captain Vasily Artemyev continues his streak of starting every game Russia have played at a Rugby World Cup. Team News - Scotland Scotland make 14 changes from their win over Samoa, with only wing Darcy Graham retaining his place. Hooker Fraser Brown starts on the openside, something he has done only once before for his country (against Argentina last summer), while Adam Hastings starts at ten. John Barclay captains the side on the blindside. Advertisement Good morning! Pool A is shaping up as perhaps the most intriguing pool at this Rugby World Cup, with Japan's win over Ireland opening the group up, and confusion and chaos around a looming typhoon further muddying the waters. Scotland know, then, that two bonus point wins might just be enough. Russia are their penultimate opponents, and kick-off is not too far away... Welcome to The Independent's live coverage of the Rugby World Cup, with Scotland looking to keep their quarter-final hopes alive as they take on already-eliminated Russia in Shizuoka.

When is it?

Scotland vs Russia kicks off at 4.15pm Japan Standard Time (8.15am BST) on Wednesday 9 October.

Where can I watch it?

The match will be broadcast on ITV1. Alternatively, you can live stream it via the ITV Hub on your smartphone, laptop or tablet.

Teams

Scotland: Blair Kinghorn; Tommy Seymour, Duncan Taylor, Pete Horne, Darcy Graham; Adam Hastings, George Horne; Gordon Reid, George Turner, Zander Fagerson; Scott Cummings, Ben Toolis; John Barclay, Fraser Brown, Ryan Wilson.

Replacements: Stuart McInally, Siomn Berghan, WP Nel, Grant Gilchrist, Magnus Bradbury, Jamie Ritchie, Henry Pyrgos, Chris Harris.

Russia: Vasily Artemyev; German Davydov, Vladimir Ostroushko, Dmitry Gerasimov, Vladislav Sozonov; Ramil Gaisin, Dmitry Perov; Valery Morozov, Stanislav Selskii, Kirill Gotovtsev; Andrey Ostrikov, Evgeny Elgin; Vitaly Zhivatov, Tagir Gadzhiev, Nikita Vavilin.

Replacements: Sergey Chernyshev, Azamat Bitiev, Vladimir Podrezov, Bogdan Fedotko, Andrey Garbuzov, Sergey Ianiushkin, Anton Sychev, Yury Kushnarev
